contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) "you have so quickly stopped trusting in him" or 2) "you have so quickly stopped being loyal to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you are turning away so quickly from him ... to a different gospel

contextId.information: They were men who taught people about Jesus and convinced people to believe in Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Possible meanings are 1) "you ... have become the same sort of person as Christ is" (UDB) or 2) "you ... have the same relationship to God as Christ." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you ... have clothed yourselves with Christ

contextId.information: The people to whom God has made promises are spoken of as if they were to inherit property and wealth from a family member. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Paul uses the metaphor of a person buying back lost property or buying the freedom of a slave as a picture of Jesus paying for his people's sins by dying on the cross. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The people to whom God has made promises are spoken of as if they were to inherit property and wealth from a family member. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is a metaphor for disciples or followers. AT: "You who are disciples because of me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Paul uses childbirth as a metaphor for his concern about the Galatians. AT: "I am in pain as though I were a woman having to give birth to you, and I will continue to be in pain until Christ truly controls you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I am in the pains of childbirth for you until Christ is formed in you

contextId.information: Hagar is a slave and her children are slaves with her. AT: "Jerusalem, like Hagar, is a slave, and her children are slaves with her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: she is in slavery with her children

contextId.information: This refers to Abraham's becoming Ishmael's father by taking Hagar as a wife. AT: "by means of human action" or "because of what people did" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Standing firm here represents being determined not to change. How they are not to change can be stated clearly. AT: "Do not give in to the arguments of people who teach something else" or "Be determined to stay free" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Stumbling represents sinning, and a stumbling block represents something that causes people to sin. In this case the sin is to reject the truth of the teaching that in order to be made right with God, people only need to believe that Jesus died on the cross for us. AT: "the teaching about the cross that causes people to reject the truth has been removed" or "there is nothing in the teaching about Jesus dying on the cross that would lead people to reject the teaching" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: the stumbling block of the cross has been removed

contextId.information: Walking is a metaphor for living. AT: "conduct your life in the power of the Holy Spirit" or "live your life in dependence on the Spirit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Paul uses fruit as a metaphor for what people can see in other people. AT: "people whom the Spirit controls will display love ... self-control like a tree produces fruit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the fruit of the Spirit is love ... self-control

contextId.information: "Walk" is a metaphor for living every day. AT: "allow the Holy Spirit to guide us so we do things that please and honor God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Planting represents doing things that end in some kind of result, and gathering in represents experiencing the results of what one has done. AT: "for just as a farmer gathers in the fruit of whatever kind of seeds he plants, so everyone experiences the results of whatever he does" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for whatever a man plants, that he will also gather in

contextId.information: "plants seed according to his sinful nature." This represents doing what he wants to do because of his sinful nature. AT: "plants seed according to what he wants because of his sinful nature" or "does the things he wants to do because of his sinful nature" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: plants seed to his own sinful nature
